heading: shuttle mission scrubbed
subheading: tuesday's liftoff of the space shuttle columbia -- the first american space mission with a woman commander -- was aborted a split-second before the engines fired up. nasa blames a faulty detector. by polly sprenger.
author: polly sprenger
text: the anniversary launch of the space shuttle columbia was scrubbed tuesday morning, just seconds before its scheduled liftoff from kennedy space center at cape carnaveral. the shuttle's hazardous gas detection system identified a high concentration of hydrogen in one of the engine compartments. the data was later shown to be erroneous, nasa said.the agency will attempt another launch on thursday.nasa said the detection system problem followed a virtually flawless countdown."system engineers in ksc's firing room no. 1 noted the indication and initiated a manual cutoff of the ground launch sequencer less than one-half second before the shuttle's three main engines would have started," nasa said.because engineers determined that the warning was false, nasa is proceeding with a standard 24-hour turnaround.thursday's launch is planned for 12:28 am edt. the aborted launch had been scheduled to coincide with the 30th anniversary of neil armstrong stepping on the moon.columbia will be commanded by eileen collins, a 42-year-old astronaut from elmira, new york. collins is the first female space shuttle commander.columbia's five-day mission will support the orbiting chandra x-ray observatory, also known as the advanced x-ray astrophysics facility imaging system. the observatory is intended to allow scientists to study phenomena such as exploding stars, quasars, and black holes.
